last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18602600
Dippin chilli sauce
Put some dark chili powder, black pepper, maybe a little bit of paprika, cayenne in a frying pan with a little oil on medium heat. Wait till it gets kinda hot. Add a little ketchup, water, stir, add some cornstarch, stir, add a splash of vinegar. It'll evaporate a lot of the water, you dont want it too watery. Stir and then pour a little of that in your little container to dip the tendies in. Its good. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604360
>Bag of citric acid off Amazon or ebay
You can also buy it next to the home canning jars at almost every super market.

>>18604796
>don't plan on brewing in the kettle, there still ends up being water residue that needs to be scrubbed off though.
If it is just lime scale then all you will need is some weak acid like citric acid. Heat some water in the kettle, put in some citric acid, let it sit for a few minutes to dissolve the lime, then rinse it out thoroughly. No scrubbing necessary. Citric acid is the active ingredient of many commercial coffee machine cleaners. Also don't let your kettle boil dry in use because it is not great for the kettle itself and because it will deposit all the remaining minerals in the water onto the bottom of the kettle. I always leave a bit of water in my kettle. If you are having to descale you kettle very frequently your water is probably harder than ideal for tea and you may want to try softening it or using bottled water for particularly fancy teas.

I am lucky and where I live now has soft, probably slightly acidic water, and I no longer have to descale my kettle. In fact I think it removed a little lime scale that had developed at my last location which had harder water.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604452
so, you'll have to visit tokyo, osaka, aomori, and hokkaido to do the main ones, but I won't tell you what those are. i will teach you how to order ramen at a real ramen shop in japan, though. first, you need to figure out where the ticket machine is. when you've located it, you need to point at it and loudly declare "MUZU MUZU WAKARIMASEN" over and over again, it's kind of shocking for foreigners but it's a different culture in restaurants in Japan and people typically call out loudly when they need service. one of the ramenyasan will come from behind the counter, you need to hand him your money and say "RAMEN' very clearly or he might just guess and order you fried rice or something. once he's pushed the button to get the ticket, he'll take the ticket back around the counter. now, if the counter is full, the traditional thing is to go stand behind someone who isn't eating quickly enough or otherwise dawdling (using their phone). you need to sigh every few seconds and stage-whisper "OSOI" (pronounced oh-soy). this is part of japanese culture and is how the "many" remind individuals that they are "jama" (in the way). this should shame the patron into leaving. after that, ask for your fork (they'll understand fork) and have at it!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18600859
I make soup most Monday mornings, in the winter. Sometimes carrot and coriander like this anon:
>>18603541
Try a little celery in with the onion.
But often variations of:
>Fry some (only 100g or so) cubetti di pancetta (bacon bits, basically) or chorizo
>turn off heat and put pan on something (heatproof) at slight angle, push the pancetta to the top and let the oil drain downhill
>come back to it in five minutes, take out and reserve the pancetta
>use that yummy bacon fat to fry onions, celery, carrot
>add whatever veg I bought (diced). One or two of: brussels, parsnips, cabbage, leeks, cauli, broc and a potato or two to thicken
>sweat for a bit
>maybe make a bouquet garni, depending on what veg
>water and a veg stockpot or cube
>s&p, maybe a small pinch of chilli flakes, cumin or garlic, depending on what veg
>gently simmer for 1/2 hr or so, stirring every ten minutes
>let cool a bit and fish out the bouquet garni if used
>blitz – usually not until smooth, we like some chunks
>chuck the pancetta back in and warm it up at lunchtime
There's usually leftovers for 2 or 3 days that we spread across the week. You don't want the same lunch every day or you'll be bored, no matter how good it is. Cheap, tasty, healthy.

threads.com: For financial reasons, I have begun to subsist on a very minimal diet. I have managed to get the amount I spend on food down to about three or four dollars per day. I was thinking of maybe eating half a jar of peanut butter per day, but this would put the amount I spend on food close to $6 per day, which I want to avoid if possible.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Let me advocate for lard. It might be a little more expensive than oil, but it'll make your bean burritos taste great. You can make your own flatbreads by mixing flour, water and lard in a roughly 8:3:1 ratio by weight. Grate the lard into to the flour, add a big pinch of salt and mix it with your hand, gradually add the water mixing constantly until there's one lump, then knead it a bit until it's even. Leave it to rest for twenty or so minutes, roll out portions and cook on a very hot skilled about 60s a side.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: How can someone who's legally blind (can only see about a foot in front of them) learn to cook? Videos and watching others cook don't help. I need to find a text/website/book that has written instructions on the most basic of things such as peeling, cutting, slicing and dicing, which cookbooks often assume the reader already knows how to do. Any ideas?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604524
cheesed to meet you!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604524
>legally blind
>written instructions
>peeling, cutting, slicing and dicing
You're gonna need someone to physically hold you by the hand and demonstrate how to do it without injuring yourself.
If you're blind it's probably better to use a food processor or some infomercial gadget instead of trying to handle a sharp knife.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604548
this, to an extent

chopping is essential and a foot away sounds too far for things like onions

however, i will say that I recently got a kitchenaid stand mixer, and the number of things the attachments can do are incredible. you have a kitchen-sized motor rotating something and they figured out they can make it do 50 things based on that alone. i got the slicing attachment and it works great.

rather than investing in a bunch of unitaskers, maybe something like that, a single device that's modifiable, will help. it's a big investment if you're not cooking already, though.

that being said, if you can actually SEE what you're doing, there's not all that much to cutting and peeling. just use the peel side of your box grater or a handheld vegetable peeler for peeling. for cutting, say, an onion, cut horizontal lines in the side of the onion, vertical lines on top, and then cut through the top horizontally and the grid will produce a usable cut. i'm sure if you search "how to cut an onion" you'll find that kind of advice, but maybe your vision is too bad to absorb it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604524
Get one of those vegetable choppers that have the different square blade types for dicing and a mandolin with a guard for slicing.

If you don't trust yourself with a standard peeler, get an automatic one or one for people with arthritis

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I had some left over corn cobs from dent corn i grew this year.

i had pound and a half of bottom round steak i got marked down at the grocery store. kind of a thin cut, maybe half or 3/4 inch thick.

as an experiment, i took the frozen steak and put it over the cobs mixed with a small amount of hardwood charcoal. my idea was that if the meat was still frozen, it would have more time exposed to the smoke to absorb more flavor from it.

i wasn't technically planning to cook it, just add the smoke flavor. but i think it was a thin enough cut that it cooked up even though i had it about a foot above the hot coals. i only had a small amount of hot coals, just enough to get the cobs to smoke. so i didn't think it would be enough heat to cook the steak.

it came out really well. my kids ate up most of it, and they are extremely picky eaters.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18603719
nice. would you do this again in the future?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18604058
absolutely. like i said, my kids are very picky. i was shocked to see them eating it up so fast. i myself thought it was pretty good. it was a bit sweet. quite tasty. very easy to do. the meat was fairly tender. i dont usually buy this cut of meat. i gather it is not considered a high quality cut. it was 'bottom round steak', whatever that is.

i dont have any kind of fancy smoker. i have been googling since i did it earlier to see what other people have done, and they all have propane burners and augers and things like that.

i just put the corn cobs and hot coals in an old stew pot we don't use anymore.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>18598578
All the local japanese restaurants are just boring sushi here and I'm tired of it.
But I went to a japanese culture festival and they imported real japanese chefs for it so I gave some stuff a shot:
-Okonomiyaki was nice. Reminded me of the german Kartoffelpuffer texture wise.
-Had some beef on rice which despite being basic was really good. The meat was nice and fatty and it soaked into the rice which gave it a lot of flavor.
-Tried the meme kobe meat and it was excellent but also prepared by a local chef, not a japanese I think.
-We bought a sealed plastic container with Natto in it. That was evil.
-Had some japanese mochi ice cream and it was underwhelming. Made me appreciate gaijin dessert culture.

I went there specifically for the food and was overall not disappointed. The remainder of the event was very lame. Cheap shit anime merch everywhere and the performances were lame too.
